titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Florence Tate Papers, 1960-2006 RL.11507
titlestmt.author: David Romine

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-03-22 15:20:04 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Florence Tate (1931-2014) was a civil rights and pan-African activist based in Washington, DC. Involved in activism in support of Angolan independence, she later worked in support of the UNITA faction in the Angolan Civil War. In the United States, she worked as a press secretary for the first mayoral administration of Marion Barry and subsequently for the 1984 presidential campaign of Jesse Jackson.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into four series: Personal Materials, Country and Subject Files, African Politics, and U.S. Politics.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Born in Eads, Tennessee in 1931, Florence L. Tate (née Grinner) grew up in Memphis where she attended public school. After earning a bachelor's degree in English from LeMoyne College, she married Charles Tate, and took a job as a reporter for the Dayton Daily News in Dayton, Ohio. While reporting on politics, courts, and schools for the newspaper, she was also heavily involved in the civil rights movement. In addition to working with the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) and the Congress Of Racial Equality (CORE), Florence and Charles Tate founded the Dayton Alliance for Racial Equality (DARE).

In the late 1960s, Florence Tate embraced pan-Africanist causes, writing for the Black News Service. She served as a key organizer in the first African Liberation Day held in May 1972. She later became involved with advocating for Angolan independence. Following Portuguese withdrawl and the nation's takeover by the Soviet-backed People's Movement for Angolan Liberation (MPLA), Tate began to work with the Union for the Total Indepdence of Angola (UNITA), an Angolan nationalist movement lead by Jonas Savimbi.
In 1979, she joined the first Marion Barry Administration in Washington, DC as press secretary and in 1984, she worked on Senator Jesse Jackson's presidential campaign as a press secretary as well.
Following Jackson's loss in the primaries, she was a political communications consultant and active organizer for political causes in and around Washington until her death in 2014.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Materials in the UNITA subseries of the African Politics Series are open for reading room research but have a view-only status. This means that researchers are not allowed to photograph or request reproductions from the UNITA materials. This restriction will be lifted in 2040.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Florence Tate Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2017.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Florence Tate Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2017-0071

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Rubenstein also holds the Judy Richardson Papers and the Courtland Cox Papers.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The largest series, African Politics, contains material from Tate's activism in support of the Southwestern African nation of Angola. As an organizer of several groups which sought to connect Angolans with African Americans, this series features correspondence, official communiques with the UNITA leadership, government documents, and clippings from African newspapers and journals.

The U.S. Politics series highlights Tate's role as a press secretary for both Mayor Marion Barry and Senator Jesse Jackson, during the latter's 1984 presidential campaign. Of particular importance is her role in organizing and documenting Jackson's 1984 mission to Syria to free downed Navy pilot Robert O. Goodman, shot down by Syrian forces over Lebanon during the height of the Lebanese Civil War.

The Name and Subject series is based on material related to organizations that Tate created and lead. She collected materials related to Kwame Ture (Stokely Carmichael) and Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin (H. Rap Brown), among others. There is also information collected related to Southern African nations of Zambia and Zimbabwe.

The Personal Materials series features correspondence, photographs, and articles written by Florence Tate. It highlights her career as a journalist in Dayton, Ohio during the mid-1960s, when she was active with local CORE and SNCC organizations.

controlaccess.subject: Civil rights movements -- United States

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series features personal correspondence, photographs, articles and press releases written by Florence Tate. It contains numerous photocopies of articles from when she was journalist for the Dayton Daily News. It also contains biographical reference sheets, papers related to firm of Florence Tate and Associates, and memorabilia from the 1963 March on Washington and a 1964 civil rights march in Dayton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Biographical sheets, funeral program. Oversize certificate for D.C. Arts and Humanities Council appointment, 1997.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopies of Florence Tate's articles in the Dayton Daily News, from Dayton, Ohio, primarily related to civil rights issues and local politics. Also contains later writing and Op-Eds by Tate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Papers related to the public relations firm of Florence Tate and Associates, which Tate began following the end of her association with the Marion Barry administration until joining Senator Jesse Jackson's 1984 presidential campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal photographs, some professional, some candid. Includes photos of Queen Mother Audley Moore, Kwame Ture, and Amiri Baraka, and numerous friends and associates from Angola.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal correspondence including Judy Richardson, Chinsole Chitunda, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pamphlets related to 1995 film festival and organizations in Washington, DC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two buttons related to the 1963 March on Washington on August 28 and one button related to a Dayton, Ohio March on June 14, 1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal Rolodex includes names, contacts, addresses, and phone numbers.

did.unittitle: March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom pennant

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series primarily organized by Florence Tate featuring materials by and related to named individuals. Material includes correspondence, published and unpublished writing by, poetry, and articles about named individuals.
In the case of Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin (H. Rap Brown), folder includes material related to his 2002 trial and conviction for manslaughter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Articles and writing by Amiri Baraka (aka LeRoi Jones)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Articles about and papers related to activism in support of Brown aka Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Articles, correspondence, and photographs by Malik Chaka

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Article by Charles Cobb

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Scholarship and articles by Courtland Cox related to Southern Africa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with Tony Fernandes, biographical information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with Marilyn Fletcher, poetry

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript entitled "Both Sides Winds of Change in Angola"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Book entitled "Angola a resistencia em busa de uma nova nacao" (Angola the resistance in search of a new nation)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Multiple copies of draft manuscript "I am a Brown Man"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, newspaper clippings, and photographs related to medical treatment and death of Kwame Ture (aka Stokely Carmichael)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series covers Florence Tate's advocacy, interest in, and organizing in support of African political movements, primarily related to Angola, but covering other states and groups in Southwestern Africa between the late 1960s and early 1990s.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in the UNITA subseries of the African Politics Series are open for reading room research but have a view-only status. This means that researchers are not allowed to photograph or request reproductions from the UNITA materials. This restriction will be lifted in 2040.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material related to the first African Liberation Day which organized simultaneous rallies in dozens of United States and Canadian cities on May 27, 1972.

Includes correspondence, press releases, research, and promotional material related to the event and to the African Liberation Day Coordinating Committee (ALDCC), based in Washington, DC and headed by Florence Tate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Detroit Committee for the Liberation of Africa Vol. 2 No. 2 1975-1976

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Check register for the African Liberation Day Coordinating Committee (ALDCC). Contains check stubs for checks written by the ALDCC for promotional materials for African Liberation Day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials related to the Friends of Angola organization, an advocacy group based in Washington, DC. Begun in support of Angolan independence, it shifted into advocacy of the UNITA faction following the Portuguese withdrawl and outbreak of civil war.
Sub-series organized by Tate, someoverlap with other sub-series, including African Services Bureau, Medical Project, and UNITA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with Richard Gibson and Jeremias Chitunda

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials related to the African Services Bureau, a short-lived organization that advocated for African nationalist movements in the United States press.
Sub-series organized by Tate, someoverlap with other sub-series, including Friends of Angola, Medical Project, and UNITA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials related to the Angolan Medical Project, an effort to bring doctors from the United States and Caribbean to Angola. Material includes résumés by applicants, correspondence with Angolans about requests, and informational materials about medical needs in Angola and Southwestern Africa.
Sub-series organized by Tate, someoverlap with other sub-series, including Friends of Angola, African Services Bureau, and UNITA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes applications, resumes, and information about medical personnel who volunteered

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Position paper from Guinean-based African Liberation Organization associated with Kwame Nkrumah and Kwame Ture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paper demanding release of "Pretoria Twelve"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials related to Angola including 1968 issue of "Noticia"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News clipping related to FESTAC, African Art Festival in Lagos

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes issue of "Africa Report" from 1975

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence

did.unittitle: Pan-African Association of Writers and Journalists in Britain

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two issues of "Ikwezi Journal" on Southwestern Africa, August 1977 and December 1978 and two issues of journal "Southern Africa" December 1975 and October 1977

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Report of the Special International Commission on the Assassination of Herbert Chitepo, Zimbabwean revolutionary

did.unittitle: Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Union for the Total Independence of Angola (Portuguese: União Nacional Independência da Angola--UNITA) was a nationalist organization organized under Portuguese colonialism. Sub-series contains a variety of materials relating to UNITA's press campaign in the United States, including press-releases, correspondence, research material, and government communiques in both English and Portuguese.
Sub-series organized by Tate. Contains material that overlaps with other sub-series, including Friends of Angola, Medical Project, and African Services Bureau.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials in the UNITA subseries of the African Politics Series are to be open for reading room research only until 2040. This includes view-only status for patron/researchers who are not allowed to photograph or request reproductions from the UNITA materials until 2040.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studies on general administration, women, and students, in Portuguese

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notebooks possbily belonging to Tate containing handwritten interview notes with Angolan diplomat Jeremias Chitunda and other individuals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of UNITA soldiers drilling, fighting, resting, and standing at attention. Some photos feature leading figures in UNITA, Jonas Savimbi and Jeremias Chitunda. Also included are photos of captured MPLA fighters, Angolan non-combatants, and conferences between UNITA and MPLA leadership. Photographs mostly undated and taken by unknown photographer(s).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Extensive collection of newspaper clippings from United States, European, and African newspapers including the Zambian Daily Mail, Washington Post, and New York Times. Topics include UNITA, MPLA, FNLA, Jonas Savimbi, Portuguese withdrawl, conditions in Angola, outbreak of civil War, Cuban intervention, Soviet imperialism in Southwestern Africa, and South African and U.S. support of UNITA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents produced by the Congress of the United States related to Angola

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents related to the exchange of students between Angola and the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "The Angolan Road to National Recovery"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes buttons supporting Nkrumah, Zimbabwe, FRELIMO and PAIGC, UPAC, Addis Ababa, and Third World Causes and one paper badge from Ethiopia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One full-sized (3' x 5') UNITA flag and one small (4" x 6") UNITA flag

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material related to Florence Tate's active role in United States Poltics, especially in the Washington, DC area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material related to Florence Tate's role as press secretary to Marion Barry's first mayoral campaign and later his first administration as mayor of Washington, D.C.. Includes correspondence, press releases, and news clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photograph of Mayor Barry and Sterling Brown

did.unittitle: Button from unspecified Marion Barry mayoral campaign

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1 button: Because Every One Matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials related to Florence Tate's role as the press secretary for Senator Jesse Jackson's 1984 presidential campaign. Includes press materials, news clippings, speeches, position papers, hand-written notebooks, and campaign promotional material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notebooks containing handwritten notes from events, including meetings with George Wallace and Sargent Shriver, Edith Austin's funeral, and the Washington Post in the aftermath of "Hymietown" gaffe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Register to Vote" and "Rainbow Coalition" campaign posters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Campaign buttons from both the 1984 and 1988 Jesse Jackson presidential campaigns. Material also includes one pin and one keychain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Boston debate, event at Shiloh

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials related to Florence Tate's involvement in Jesse Jackson's mission to Syria in 1983-1984 to negotiate the release of Black airman Michael O. Goodman. Goodman, a Navy navigator, had been shot down over Syria during a mission related to the Lebaneses Civil War and was held by Syrian forces for several weeks. Jackson, along with a number of other Black religious leaders, petittioned the Syrian government of Hafez Al-Assad to free the airman since the United States and Syria were not at war.
Includes meeting notes, schedules, security arrangements, Embassy materials, news clippings, photographs, and contact sheets from Syria Mission

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
